results.name: The Captain's Log
results.description:
This ship's computer will keep track of your progress in the Captain's Log.  But first you need to identify yourself to the Log Computer.

### Objective:
Your current name is `@PLAYER_USERNAME@`.   Please change this to your real name and also add your email address.  This will be important to have a chance to win prizes.

### Specifications:
In the top right corner, click on "Settings"
Change the User Name for your full name:  e.g.  John Smith
Change the Email address:  e.g. jsmith@mycompany.com

Once completed, enter "DONE" in the flag section and click submit to receive your first point!

NOTE: Once you change your name, you will have to use this new name for future logins to the game application.<script>fixupClusterDomain()</script>

results.name: Unlock the ship
results.description:
Wait for the game master to provide a KEY to unlock the rest of the station.  
Enter this key in the flag section and click submit.

results.name: Engine Trouble
results.description:
As you explore the station, you come across the main engine room and notice a troubling sight: the ships engine, a late model StarLight XL, is broken beyond repair; a tangle of scorched circuits and shattered components! With no other options, you scour the storage bays and, to your relief, find a brand new QuantumPulse Thruster 3000 waiting to be installed! After some effort, you manage to replace the broken engine with the new one.
However, a new problem arises. The HAL 8000 AI, which controls the station's systems, has no knowledge of this new QuantumPulse model! Without understanding how to operate it, HAL 8000 can't start or manage the new engine. In your search for solutions, hidden within the bubble-wrap for the engine, you discover the [QuantumPulse 3000 Owner's Manual](https://gitea-gitea.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@/starter/INSTRUCTIONS/raw/branch/master/resources/quantumpulse-3000.md)! This manual is your key to bringing HAL 8000 up to speed, but it needs to be processed into a format the AI can understand. You'll need to implement a Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG) system to enable HAL 8000 to access and learn from the manual. ### Objective: Your first task is to deploy a vector database, ChromaDB, within the OpenShift cluster. This database will store embeddingsâ€”numerical representations of textâ€”from the new engine manual. Once ChromaDB is operational, HAL 8000 can query it to retrieve crucial information about the engine's operation. ### Specification: A container image for chromadb can be found in a public container registry at `quay.io/atgreen0/chroma:latest`. Try deploying chromadb in your namespace. Looking at the chroma startup logs, how many components does it start? * ocp: https://console-openshift-console.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@

results.name: Chunk It Up
results.description:
In order to populate your vector database, you will need to split up the [QuantumPulse 3000's Owner Manual](https://gitea-gitea.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@/starter/INSTRUCTIONS/raw/branch/master/resources/quantumpulse-3000.md) into smaller chunks of text before feeding those to an embedding model to generate vectors for the vector database.  But we can take this one step at a time.

### Objective:
Write code to read the markdown-formatted Owner's Manual, and split it up into fixed chunk sizes. Count the number of chunks.

### Specification:
Each chunk size should contain eight paragraphs of text.  More specifically, for the purposes of this challenge, any fragment of text separated by a blank line is a paragraph, even if it is only one line long (eg. a section header).  The final chunk may be less than eight paragraphs.  For now, we don't need to save the chunks anywhere -- just count them.

How many eight-paragraph chunks exist in the [QuantumPulse 3000's Owner Manual](https://gitea-gitea.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@/starter/INSTRUCTIONS/raw/branch/master/resources/quantumpulse-3000.md)?

* gitea: https://gitea-gitea.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@
* ocp: https://console-openshift-console.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@
* manual: https://gitea-gitea.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@/starter/INSTRUCTIONS/raw/branch/master/resources/quantumpulse-3000.md
 <script>fixupClusterDomain()</script>

results.name: Embedding
results.description:
An embedding model is an AI model specifically trained to generate long lists of numbers (vectors) representing the semantic meaning of a chunk of text.  You can read more about embedding models here: https://ollama.com/blog/embedding-models

You'll need an embedding model to populate your vector database with the text you will chunk out from the [QuantumPulse 3000's Owner Manual](https://gitea-gitea.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@/starter/INSTRUCTIONS/raw/branch/master/resources/quantumpulse-3000.md). Fortunately, Space Command provided an emedding model (`nomic-embed-text`) that you should be able to deploy on the ship's OpenShift cluster.

## Objective:
Deploy and test an embedding model on OpenShift.

## Specifications:
There's an embedding model available for deployment at `quay.io/atgreen0/ollama-embedding:latest`.  Deploy this container image in your namespace.  To ensure that it is working, let's generate our first vector.   In the model's pod terminal run this:
```
curl http://localhost:8080/api/embeddings -d '{
  "model": "nomic-embed-text",
  "prompt": "The speed of light in a vacuum is approximately 299,792,458 m/s."
}'
```
The model should have responded with a JSON object containing a vector of numbers.  What is the very last number in the vector?

* ocp: https://console-openshift-console.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@
 <script>fixupClusterDomain()</script>

results.name: API service down
results.description:
The silence aboard the space station is overwhelming as you survey the dimly lit control room. The ship's computer, HAL8000, which once managed all station functions and provided valuable API endpoints, is completely offline. Without it, you're cut off from the ship's vital systems, unable to monitor resources or communicate with the outside universe. You must act swiftly to restore HAL8000 before it's too late.

### Objective:
Your task is to restart the HAL8000 API service using OpenShift. Once operational, this service will be your lifeline, allowing you to interface with the ship's systems in future challenges.


### Specification:

A container image for the api service can be found in a public container registry at 
`quay.io/atgreen0/ship_api:latest`

In your designated project (namespace), `@PLAYER_USERNAME@`, run this image as a container pod and make sure to add a route to be able to reach this service.   This can easily be done in Add=>Container image.

Finally, to retrieve the oxygen level on the ship, hit the following api endpoint with your browser: `/api/v1/oxygen`

Retrieve the oxygen level and use it as your flag to complete the challenge and restore a critical part of the station.

* ocp: https://console-openshift-console.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@

 <script>fixupClusterDomain()</script>

results.name: Temperature control
results.description:
### Objective:
Let's validate that the ambient temperature on the ship is ok.


### Specification:

Use the ship computer api service again to retrieve the temperature on the ship for all the rooms.    You should already have the api service running from the warm up phase,  just reach the temperature api endpoint to retrieve this information: `/api/v1/temperature`

Let's calculate the average temperature on the ship and return that value as the flag to get your points.

* ocp: https://console-openshift-console.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@
 <script>fixupClusterDomain()</script>

results.name: Speed control
results.description:
### Objective:
As we are approaching planet Nerdoria's orbit, we realize that we might not arrive on time.   Punctuality is very important for Nerdorians, we must arrive exactly at 7pm Nerdoria Standard Time.    Adjust your ship speed to make sure we arrive exactly on-time.


### Specification:

Use the ship api service again to look at our front camera and detect the exact distance between our ship and this planet.   You can access this front camera at: `/api/v1/camera1`

Then, adjust the speed of our ship in km/s to arrive exactly at 7:00pm NST.     The current time on Nedoria is 1:16pm.
This can be done by doing an HTTP POST to the speed control api: `/api/v1/speed`

Our reputation is in your hands.    

If the speed is adjusted correctly, the API server will give you the right flag.     If the speed is incorrect, you might get a wrong flag.

* ocp: https://console-openshift-console.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@
 <script>fixupClusterDomain()</script>

results.name: RAG Service
results.description:
Now that we have a working embedding model and Vector DB, it's time to build the service the ship's AI will call to ask about the [QuantumPulse 3000's Owner Manual](https://gitea-gitea.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@/starter/INSTRUCTIONS/raw/branch/master/resources/quantumpulse-3000.md).
## Objective:
Implement a service on the ship's OpenShift cluster that will accept posts from the ship's AI, and find relevant text from the vector DB.  To solve this, you will need to write a service that will:
- populate the vectordb with the chunked text you have already created.
- respond to https posts from the ship's AI to find the closest matching text from the DB.

To retrieve the flag, tell the API server to test your implementation by hitting the `/api/v1/test-rag` endpoint.

## Specifications:
**Endpoint:** POST /

**Input:** Plain text body describing what the AI wants to learn about.

**Response:** JSON output from the vector database.

The **starter** user on gitea contains sample starter repos showing how to interact with the vector DB

* ocp: https://console-openshift-console.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@
* node RAG starter: https://gitea-gitea.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@/starter/node-rag-starter
* python RAG starter: https://gitea-gitea.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@/starter/python-rag-starter
* java RAG starter: https://gitea-gitea.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@/starter/java-rag-starter
 <script>fixupClusterDomain()</script>

results.name: Turtle Count
results.description:
A deeper inspection of the Chelonid's message fragments reveals that the sequence numbers of the fragments are arriving out of order.  This must be due to some additional damage to the ship's input array buffer.  The good news is that the Chelonids are sending the same series of message fragments over and over again in a repeating loop, so if you wait long enough you are sure to capture them all and will be able to sort them.

### Objective

Determine the length of the repeating Chelonid message.

### Specification

The instructions are arriving out of order, but once they are sorted they start at 1 and each instruction step goes up by 1.  The sequence of instructions ends with an empty `instruction` ("") and is not included in the total count of sequence steps.

Your flag is simply the number of steps in the message sequence.

* ocp: https://console-openshift-console.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@
* gitea: https://gitea-gitea.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@
 <script>fixupClusterDomain()</script>

results.name: Turtle Draw
results.description:
Now that you've received all of the instruction steps, it's time to decode the message (your flag).

Upon careful examination, you realize that the instruction steps are reminiscent of the old "turtle graphics" used in computer programming. These instructions direct a virtual pen to move and draw patterns, revealing hidden messages when interpreted correctly.

### Objective

Your objective is to move a virtual pen-wielding turtle through a two-dimensional grid in order to render an image that will reveal their message (your flag).

### Specification

Turtle graphics are written on a two-dimensional grid.  Each cell in the grid starts off empty.  A cell is marked with `#` whenever the pen is placed down in a cell, or the turtle travels through a cell while the pen is down.  The turtle can only travel forward, turn left 90 degrees, and turn right 90 degrees.

Instructions include the following commands:
- `PU`: lift the pen up
- `PD`: place the pen down
- `F[number]`: move forward `[number]` grid cells
- `R`: turn right 90 degrees
- `L`: turn left 90 degrees

Follow the Chelonids' instructions in order, starting with instruction 1.  Display the final grid in your console logs or on a web page in order to retrieve the flag for this challenge.

* ocp: https://console-openshift-console.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@
* gitea: https://gitea-gitea.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@
 <script>fixupClusterDomain()</script>

results.name: Planet database
results.description:
### Objective:
ðŸš¨ Alert! ðŸš¨ We've got smoke billowing out of the mechanical room!

The good news? Our top-notch robot mechanic, R2FixU, has already pinpointed the issue. The bad news? Fixing it in the cold, unforgiving void of space is a no-go. We need to land, and we need to land fastâ€”before things get as messy as a Wookieeâ€™s hairball.

First things first, let's fire up the ol' planet database and find the nearest rock we can safely park this hunk of metal on. 


### Specification:

A container image with the database can be found in a public container registry at 
`quay.io/mberube/planetdb:latest`

Launch this image on OpenShift and make sure to use the following environment variables to configure your database properly:

* MYSQL_ROOT_PASSWORD
* MYSQL_DATABASE
* MYSQL_USER
* MYSQL_PASSWORD

Feel free to set those variables to any value you want.  just make sure that you will remember those values as you will need to connect to this database.

In this database, you will find a "planets" table.   Find a way to count the number of planets listed in this table.    Type the number of planet as your flag.

* ocp: https://console-openshift-console.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@ <script>fixupClusterDomain()</script>

results.name: Closest planet
results.description:
### Objective:
Now that our database is running, let's find the cloest planet.   Our current ship coordinates are:  

galactic_latitude = 15.23
galactic_longitude = 95.3


### Specification:

Look into your gitea repository, you should find some code helping you get started and connect to a mysql database.     Modify this code to find the closest planet to our current location.

Type the name of this planet as the flag below to get your points.


* ocp: https://console-openshift-console.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@ <script>fixupClusterDomain()</script>

results.name: Hello World
results.description:
As you make progress in restoring the station's systems, you notice that the external communications relay is still offline. Without it, you won't be able to contact the Interstellar Federation for a rescue. The relayâ€™s systems are controlled by a simple application code stored in your Gitea repository, but it hasnâ€™t been deployed yet. Your mission is to deploy it within the OpenShift cluster to bring the relay back online.

### Objective:

 Deploy the python-starter application from your Gitea account. This application contains the key to restarting the station's communication relay and capturing the data needed to reconnect with the Federation.


### Specifications:

The Gitea `starter` account contains a project called `python-starter`. This is the code for a basic web server that will restore the communications relay.  Fork this repository into your own Gitea account.

Use OpenShift to deploy the python-starter project from the Gitea repository in your designated namespace. Expose it as a service so the relay can begin transmitting signals again.

Once deployed, access the web server, where you'll find the FLAG that confirms the relay is back online at `https://hello-@PLAYER_USERNAME@.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@/`. Use this FLAG to complete the challenge.

* ocp: https://console-openshift-console.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@
* gitea: https://gitea-gitea.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@
* starters: https://gitea-gitea.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@/starter
 <script>fixupClusterDomain()</script>

results.name: Turtle Comms
results.description:
As you delve deeper into the mysteries of the space station, your exploration brings you to an unexpected discovery. In a remote section of the station, you find a communication relay buzzing with faint activity. The source of the signal is puzzlingâ€”a race of space-faring turtles known as the Chelonids, Interstellar Federation members who communicate through intricate patterns and symbols.
These beings, renowned for their wisdom and ancient knowledge, are trying to send you a message, but their communication method is unlike anything you've seen before. It appears as through their message is being sent in fragments of instructions that must be assembled together in order to be interpreted correctly. But as the communications relay is unreliable, you will need to build a new one to start receiving uncorrupted message fragments. ### Objective Your first objective is to create an API service that can receive the turtle instruction messages. ### Specification Implement an http service that listens for incoming JSON POST messages containing turtle instructions. The service should be called `turtlecomms` and the endpoint is `/instruction`. JSON messages will be posted to `turtlecomms` via http on port 8080. The ship is routing incoming messages through the HAL8000 `ship-api` service you've already deployed, so there is no need to provide an external route to this service. Each message will contain a sequence number (`seq`), an instruction string (`instruction`) and a checksum string (`checksum`). Your first flag is simply the `checksum` value from any one of the messages. * ocp: https://console-openshift-console.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@ * gitea: https://gitea-gitea.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@

results.name: Diplomacy Key
results.description:
As you approach Pandora for your emergency landing, scans show that the planet belongs to a highly advanced alien civilization, one with strict diplomatic protocols. Miscommunication could be disastrous, leading to hostile reactions or even worseâ€”your shipâ€™s destruction.

Fortunately, the HAL 8000 system has identified a secret diplomatic code stored in the station's Kubernetes infrastructure, hidden within a file in a persistent volume. This "Diplomacy Key" is the only way to safely request landing and ensure peaceful negotiations with the planet's inhabitants.

Your mission is to locate the file, extract passphrase found within, and use it to transmit a diplomatic landing request before it's too late. Fail, and the automated defenses of the planet will see your descent as an act of aggression. Succeed, and you might just secure safe passage.

* ocp: https://console-openshift-console.apps.@CLUSTER_DOMAIN@
 <script>fixupClusterDomain()</script>
